content: Did Eugene Schieffelin release birds into Central Park with the intention of introducing every bird species mentioned in William Shakespeare's works to North America?

Yes, Eugene Schieffelin is famous for releasing about sixty European starlings into Central Park in New York City in 1890 and another sixty in 1891. His goal was indeed to introduce all the bird species mentioned in the works of William Shakespeare to North America. Schieffelin was a member of the American Acclimatization Society, which aimed to introduce useful plants and animals from Europe to North America.

The starling, which is not native to North America, was one of the species Schieffelin introduced. The European starling is mentioned in Shakespeare's play "Henry IV, Part 1," where Hotspur talks about teaching a starling to speak. Schieffelin's efforts were part of a broader movement at the time to bring familiar European flora and fauna to America.

However, the introduction of the European starling has had significant ecological consequences. Starlings are now one of the most common bird species in North America, with an estimated population of over 200 million. They are considered invasive species because they outcompete native birds for nesting sites and food resources, sometimes causing harm to local ecosystems.

Schieffelin's actions serve as a cautionary tale about the unintended consequences of introducing non-native species into new environments.
